Deficiency Narrative: There is sufficient evidence to show that staff have been yelling at the children.
Correction Narrative:
There is sufficient evidence to show that staff have been yelling at the children. 


Children were interviewed regarding discipline practices and there were no concerns noted.

Deficiency Narrative: During the course of the investigation it was determined that children in care has time out for up to 2 hours.
Correction Narrative: On 5/13/24, 3 children were interviewed regarding discipline at the operation. When asked about standing on the wall, the children stated that this no longer happens at the facility.

Deficiency Narrative: A staff member conducted a personal restraint on a child in care for a minute and a half.
Correction Narrative:
On 04/15/2024 a corrective action plan was received from the operation stating the caregiver involved will undergo retraining on the proper procedures for releasing a child from short personal restraint. The training will emphasize the importance of prompt release within one minute, sooner, or after behavior has de-escalated, and supervise the caregiver to ensure compliance with the EBI skills moving forward. This will involve closer monitoring during his interactions with children and evaluations of their performance. Continuous improvement in care giving practices and feedback will be regularly obtained from children regarding staff members interaction, work ethics, and practices. 

On 4/30/24 children were interviewed regarding restraints, when asked about the time length children stated that they are not held in restraints for a long time. They stated that the restraints last about a minute long. No concerns were found during the interviews, and children made no outcries of long-lasting restraints.

Deficiency Narrative: A staff member referenced to a child in care by an unnecessary name when the child was escalated.
Correction Narrative:
On 04/15/2024 an action plan letter was received stating the staff involved was immediately suspended pending the investigation then was reinstated with conditions of training, closed supervision, changes of responsibilities, and change of shift. All caregivers will be reminded of their obligation to treat our children with dignity, respect, and professionalism at all times.

On 4/30/24 children were interviewed regarding staff interactions. The children stated that they are not called out of their names or taunted by staff members. No concerns were found during the interviews, and no children made outcries.

Deficiency Narrative: It was found during the investigation that a child was restrained near the stairs, which creates an increased risk of harm.  Additionally, the child was rubbing their head on the carpet as a means of self-harm, which posed less risk than the actual restraint.
Correction Narrative:
On 4/16/24 a corrective action plan was received from the operation: "The caregiver involved in the incident has been informed of the importance of considering the potential risk of harm when implementing his EBI skills. The caregiver involved in the incident now understands from scenarios and practical examples explained to him the risk of harm using EBI versus the risk of not using EBI. The caregiver will make an informed decision in the event EBI is utilized.
All caregivers will take into consideration harmful factors and the risk of using EBI versus the risk of not using EBI. The administrator, facility manager, and shift supervisors will ensure in the event EBI is utilized to take into consideration the potential risk of harm associated with using EBI versus not using EBI.
All Caregivers will be required to document the location within the faculty in the event EBI is required. This documentation will be reviewed by the administrator to ensure compliance and identify any areas for improvement."

On 4/30/24 children were interviewed regarding EBI at the facility and no concerns were found. No children made any outcries regarding EBI.

Deficiency Narrative: It was found during the investigation that a child in care received significant bruising to their shoulder after a short personal restraint.
Correction Narrative:
On 4/16/24 a corrective action plan was received from the operation: "The caregiver involved in the incident has been informed to use a minimal amount of reasonable and necessary physical force whenever EBI is implemented. The administrator discussed with the caregiver involved in the incident the concept of minimal physical force and its application in caregiving scenarios. EBI Refresher Training will continue to be vital in ensuring that all staff members are up to date with the latest procedures, regulations, and best practices. Additionally, ongoing refresher training fosters a culture of continuous learning, improvement, professionalism, and accountability across the board within New Day Foundation. New Day Foundations EBI training will include de-escalation techniques, the importance of applying minimal physical force, and scenarios to reinforce learning skills in effective intervention. New Day Foundation will implement these corrective actions and prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. We recognize the importance of providing a safe and supportive environment for our children and are dedicated to upholding the highest standards of care and professionalism in our facility."

On 4/30/24, children were interviewed regarding EBI and were specifically ask about the amount of force when a restraint is done on them. When asked about the force being used, children stated that there isn't enough forced used to get hurt after the restraint. The children stated they have never received any bruising or injuries after being restrained. No children made any outcries about EBI during the interview. No concerns were found.

Deficiency Narrative: The administrator reported becoming aware of the child's absence around 4pm of 05/19/23; the report was made to SWI at 1:24am on 05/20/23.
Correction Narrative:
An inspection was completed today at the operation, and staff was interviewed regarding runaways and reporting. There were no concerns with the interview. 

Written corrections received from the operation: I informed all our staff members as the administrator to call DFPS within the required 6 hours' time.

Deficiency Narrative:
During a review conducted on March 31, 2023, it was determined that: 
(1)	your operations administrator failed to ensure compliance with the current HM Plan(s); and 
(2)	more than 12 months had elapsed since the effective date of the plan.
As you know, the heightened monitoring plans for your operation included a specific planned end date at the original 12-month mark by which your operation was expected to meet all heightened monitoring criteria necessary to move out of active heightened monitoring to a phase of post plan monitoring.  As a direct result of the administrators failure to ensure timely compliance with heightened monitoring plans, your operation was unable to successfully move to post-plan monitoring by the original planned end date necessitating previous extension.  Furthermore, due to your recent citation issued on September 22, 2022, your operations planned end date must now be revised again, and the period of heightened monitoring must be extended again. 
Further details of the administrators failure to ensure compliance include the following: 
Your operation received a high-weighted citation in a pattern/trend category on September 22, 2022.  Specifically, the operation was cited for 748.685(a)(5) Caregiver responsibility - being able to intervene when necessary to ensure child's safety. The operation met compliance on October 7, 2022.  
-	Operation failed to demonstrate 6 months of successive compliance with the standard and contract requirements that led to heightened monitoring.
-	Operation was unable to meet compliance with Medium-High or High weighted licensing citations.
Finding: 748.535(2)  The licensed administrator must ensure the operation complies with current heightened monitoring plans.
Correction Narrative: An HM extension was approved effective 3/31/2023.  In conjunction with this extension, a new deadline was established by which all requirements must be completed by your CPA/GRO in order for the operation to be released from its HM plan and move to the Post-plan Monitoring Stage of HM.  Because the extended deadline is now effective, HHSC has determined that the operation is compliant with the requirements of 26 TAC 748.535(2).  The HM deadline for your operation has been extended by 6 months and the new deadline is 10/1/2023.

Deficiency Narrative:
During a review conducted on September 30, 2022, it was determined that:

(1) your operations administrator failed to ensure  compliance with the current HM Plan(s); and

(2) 12 months had elapsed since the effective date of the plan.

As you know, the heightened monitoring plans for your
operation included a specific "planned end date at the
12-month mark by which your operation was expected to meet all heightened monitoring criteria necessary to move out of active heightened monitoring to a phase of post plan monitoring. As a direct result of the administrators failure to ensure timely compliance with heightened monitoring plans, your operation is now unable to successfully move to post-plan monitoring.  

Further details of the administrators failure to ensure compliance include the following: 

Your operation received a High-weighted citation in a pattern/trend category on September 22, 2022.  Specifically, the operation was cited for 748.685(a)(5) Caregiver responsibility - being able to intervene when necessary to ensure child's safety.  The operation has not met compliance.   

-	Operation failed to demonstrate 6 months of successive compliance with the standard and contract requirements that led to heightened monitoring; and
-	Operation was unable to meet compliance with Medium-High or High weighted licensing citations.
Correction Narrative: An HM extension was approved effective 9/30/2022.  In conjunction with this extension, a new deadline was established by which all requirements must be completed by your CPA/GRO in order for the operation to be released from its HM plan and move to the Post-plan Monitoring Stage of HM.  Because the extended deadline is now effective, HHSC has determined that the operation is compliant with the requirements of 26 TAC 748.535(2).  The HM deadline for your operation has been extended by 6 months and the new deadline is 3/30/2023.

Deficiency Narrative: It's confirmed that a physical restraint took place; the operation was unable to produce the necessary documentation following the intervention.
Correction Narrative:
The following email was provided by the administrator:

748.2855(a) EBI Documentation-Caregiver must document EBI in child's record as soon as possible, but no later than 24 hours after initiation of the intervention.

Specifics It's confirmed that a physical restraint took place; the operation was unable to produce the necessary documentation following the intervention.

Corrective Actions Planned and/or Taken:
New Day Foundation immediately conducted a general staff meeting regarding DFPS standard 748.2855(a)

New Day Foundations staff members will henceforth document the EBI when perform and inform the administrator after each intervention

The administrator will review all EBI documents and meet with the child after the intervention / the next business day. 

The Case Manger will ensure and has been designated to placed / file all EBI documents in a childs record.

New Day Foundations case manager will give / make available all EBI documents to DFPS workers upon request

Target Implementation/Completion Date:
Implementation effective immediately as of February 3rd, 2022 and ongoing. staff meetings and   Inservice training focusing on the importance of documentation and record keeping will continue indefinitely. 

Responsible For Implementation:
       1.The administrator and the Case Manger will ensure EBI documents are review and place in the childs record. New Day Foundation's philosophy, program model, therapeutic interventions will be implemented in the delivery of services. All services and interventions will be documented and place in the childs record.

Thanks 
Isaac Karnley/Administrator
